columns.text: This exercise requires us to determine the effect of stock split and reverse stock split on the equity accounts, new shares outstanding and new par value of share.

## Requirement a

**Stock Split** is a company action that increases the number of outstanding shares while decreasing the market value of each shares. Although the number of outstanding shares increases and price per share decreases, the total shareholders' equity does not change.

Given that the company declares a four-for-one stock split, let's first compute the new shares outstanding after the stock split by multiplying the share outstanding by the number of stock split.

$$\begin{aligned} \text{New Shares Outstanding} 
&= \text{Share Outstanding}\times{\text{Stock split}}\\[5pt] 
&= \text{50,000}\times{4}\\[5pt] &=\boxed{\textbf{200,000 shares}}\\ 
\end{aligned}$$

**As can be seen, the number of shares outstanding increased from 50,000 to 20,000 shares.**

Next, we will compute the new par value by dividing the par value by the stock split.

$$\begin{aligned} \text{New Par Value} &= \dfrac{\text{Par Value}}{\text{Stock Split}}\\[10pt] 
&= \dfrac{\text{\$\hspace{5pt}0.50}}{\text{4}}\\[10pt] 
&=\boxed{\textbf{\$\hspace{5pt}0.125}}\\ 
\end{aligned}$$

**As can be seen, the par value per share decreased from $0.50 to $0.125.**

Next, let's compute the total common stock after the stock split by multiplying the new shares outstanding by the new par value.

$$\begin{aligned} \text{Common Stock} 
&= \text{New Share Outstanding}\times{\text{New Par Value}}\\[5pt] 
&= \text{200,000}\times{\$ 0.125}\\[5pt] 
&=\boxed{\textbf{\$ 25,000}}\\ 
\end{aligned}$$

**Therefore, there is no effect of stock split on the value of the common stock.**

**The value of the capital surplus and retained earnings will be the same after the stock split.** Additionally, there is no journal entry recorded for a stock split instead, the company prepares a memo entry.

## Requirement b

**Reverse stock split** decreases the number of share in a company and cause a increase of market price of individual shares. Although the number of outstanding shares decreases and price per share increases, the total shareholders' equity does not change.

Given that the company declares a one-for-five reverse stock split, let's first compute the new shares outstanding after the reverse stock split by dividing the share outstanding by the number of reverse stock split.

$$\begin{aligned} \text{New Shares Outstanding} &= \dfrac{\text{Shares Outstanding}}{\text{Reverse Stock Split}}\\[10pt] 
&= \dfrac{\text{50,000}}{\text{5}}\\[10pt] 
&=\boxed{\textbf{10,000 shares}}\\ 
\end{aligned}$$

**As can be seen, the number of shares outstanding decreased from 50,000 to 10,000 shares.**

Next, we will compute the new par value by multiplying the par value by the reverse stock split.

$$\begin{aligned} \text{New Par Value} 
&= \text{Par Value}\times{\text{Reverse Stock split}}\\[5pt] 
&= \text{\$} 0.50\times{5}\\[5pt] 
&=\boxed{\textbf{\$ 2.50}}\\ 
\end{aligned}$$

**As can be seen, the par value per share increased from $0.50 to $2.50.**

Next, let's compute the total common stock after the reverse stock split by multiplying the new shares outstanding by the new par value.

$$\begin{aligned} \text{Common Stock} 
&= \text{New Share Outstanding}\times{\text{New Par Value}}\\[5pt] 
&= \text{10,000}\times{\$ 2.50}\\[5pt] 
&=\boxed{\textbf{\$ 25,000}}\\ 
\end{aligned}$$

**Still, there is no effect of reverse stock split on the value of the common stock.**
**The value of the capital surplus and retained earnings will be the same after the reverse stock split.**
